mn82:1.1.comm: The story of Raṭṭhapāla, the “guardian of the nation”, has become one of the most famous and beloved parables from early Buddhism. It is a testament to a young man’s resolution to go forth out of faith, a quality for which he was later honored (AN 1.210:1.1). But the power of Raṭṭhapāla’s determination should not overshadow the moving conversation he has with King Koravya at the end.

mn82:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kurūsu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ yena thullakoṭṭhikaṃ nāma kurūnaṃ nigamo tadavasari.
mn82:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kurus together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a town of the Kurus named Thullakoṭṭhika.
mn82:1.2.comm: Thullakoṭṭhika (“place of fat granaries”; Sanskrit sthūlakoṣṭhaka) only appears in the story of Raṭṭhapāla.

mn82:2.1.eng: The brahmins and householders of Thullakoṭṭhika heard:

mn82:2.2.pli: “samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo sakyaputto sakyakulā pabbajito kurūsu cārikaṃ caramāno mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ thullakoṭṭhikaṃ anuppatto.
mn82:2.2.eng: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Thullakoṭṭhika, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.

mn82:2.3.pli: Taṃ kho pana bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

mn82:2.4.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
mn82:2.4.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’

mn82:2.5.pli: So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
mn82:2.5.eng: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.

mn82:2.6.pli: So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
mn82:2.6.eng: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.

mn82:2.7.pli: Sādhu kho pana tathārūpānaṃ arahataṃ dassanaṃ hotī”ti.
mn82:2.7.eng: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”

mn82:3.1.pli: Atha kho thullakoṭṭhikā brāhmaṇagahapatikā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā appekacce bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu; appekacce bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu, sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu; appekacce yena bhagavā tenañjaliṃ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu; appekacce bhagavato santike nāmagottaṃ sāvetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu; appekacce tuṇhībhūtā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
mn82:3.1.eng: Then the brahmins and householders of Thullakoṭṭhika went up to the Buddha. Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.

mn82:3.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinne kho thullakoṭṭhike brāhmaṇagahapatike bhagavā dhammiyā kathāya sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṃsesi.
mn82:3.2.eng: When they were seated, the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired them with a Dhamma talk.

mn82:4.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena raṭṭhapālo nāma kulaputto tasmiṃyeva thullakoṭṭhike aggakulassa putto tissaṃ parisāyaṃ nisinno hoti.
mn82:4.1.eng: Now at that time a gentleman named Raṭṭhapāla, the son of the leading clan in Thullakoṭṭhika, was sitting in the assembly.

mn82:4.3.pli: “yathā yathā khvāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, nayidaṃ sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ ekantaparisuddhaṃ saṅkhalikhitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carituṃ.
mn82:4.3.eng: “As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
mn82:4.3.comm: From this point, the narrative is largely echoed in the story of Sudinna (Bu Pj 1:5.1.7), with, however, a very different outcome. While the exact relationship between these shared narratives is not easy to determine, it seems likely that Sudinna’s story adopted elements of Raṭṭhapāla’s.

mn82:4.4.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyan”ti.
mn82:4.4.eng: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from lay life to homelessness?”

mn82:5.1.pli: Atha kho thullakoṭṭhikā brāhmaṇagahapatikā bhagavatā dhammiyā kathāya sandassitā samādapitā samuttejitā sampahaṃsitā bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkamiṃsu.
mn82:5.1.eng: Then, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, the brahmins and householders of Thullakoṭṭhika got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right, before leaving.

mn82:6.1.pli: Atha kho raṭṭhapālo kulaputto acirapakkantesu thullakoṭṭhikesu brāhmaṇagahapatikesu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho raṭṭhapālo kulaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn82:6.1.eng: Soon after they left, Raṭṭhapāla went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

mn82:6.2.pli: “yathā yathāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, nayidaṃ sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ ekantaparisuddhaṃ saṅkhalikhitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carituṃ.
mn82:6.2.eng: “Sir, as I understand the Buddha’s teaching, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.

mn82:6.3.pli: Icchāmahaṃ, bhante, kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajituṃ.
mn82:6.3.eng: I wish to shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

mn82:6.4.pli: Labheyyāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyaṃ upasampadaṃ.
mn82:6.4.eng: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?

mn82:6.5.eng: May the Buddha please give me the going forth!”

mn82:6.6.pli: “Anuññātosi pana tvaṃ, raṭṭhapāla, mātāpitūhi agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāyā”ti?
mn82:6.6.eng: “But, Raṭṭhapāla, do you have your parents’ permission?”
mn82:6.6.comm: This Vinaya rule is not mentioned elsewhere in the suttas, although it was required also of Sudinna (Bu Pj 1:5.1.14). It was instituted on the emotional request of the Buddha’s own father, who was distraught when his grandson Rāhula went forth while still a boy (Kd 1:54.4.2). It originally applied to novices, who went forth as young as fifteen or “when old enough to scare crows” (Kd 1:51.1.14). Over time the requirements for ordination tend to become stricter as things required in a particular context are applied generally. If this is the case here, the process must have happened quickly, so that even in the canonical full ordination procedure a candidate, who must be twenty years at least, must have permission of their parents (Kd 1:76.1.12). However, there are many people who cannot get such permission, such as orphans. Thus if one does give the going-forth to someone without permission of the parents, it is a minor offence of wrong-doing for the mendicant performing the ordination, but it does not invalidate it (Kd 1:54.6.5).

mn82:6.7.pli: “Na khohaṃ, bhante, anuññāto mātāpitūhi agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāyā”ti.

mn82:6.8.pli: “Na kho, raṭṭhapāla, tathāgatā ananuññātaṃ mātāpitūhi puttaṃ pabbājentī”ti.
mn82:6.8.eng: “Raṭṭhapāla, Buddhas don’t give the going forth to the child of parents who haven’t given their permission.”

mn82:6.9.pli: “Svāhaṃ, bhante, tathā karissāmi yathā maṃ mātāpitaro anujānissanti agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāyā”ti.
mn82:6.9.eng: “I’ll make sure, sir, to get my parents’ permission.”

mn82:7.1.pli: Atha kho raṭṭhapālo kulaputto uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā yena mātāpitaro tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā mātāpitaro etadavoca:
mn82:7.1.eng: Then Raṭṭhapāla got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha. Then he went to his parents and said,

mn82:7.2.pli: “ammatātā, yathā yathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, nayidaṃ sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ ekantaparisuddhaṃ saṅkhalikhitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carituṃ.
mn82:7.2.eng: “Mum and dad, as I understand the Buddha’s teachings, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.

mn82:7.3.pli: Icchāmahaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajituṃ.
mn82:7.3.eng: I wish to shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

mn82:7.4.eng: Please give me permission to go forth.”

mn82:7.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, raṭṭhapālassa kulaputtassa mātāpitaro raṭṭhapālaṃ kulaputtaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn82:7.5.eng: When he said this, Raṭṭhapāla’s parents said to him,

mn82:7.6.pli: “tvaṃ khosi, tāta raṭṭhapāla, amhākaṃ ekaputtako piyo manāpo sukhedhito sukhaparibhato.
mn82:7.6.eng: “But, dear Raṭṭhapāla, you’re our only child. You’re dear to us and we love you. You’re dainty and raised in comfort.

mn82:7.7.pli: Na tvaṃ, tāta raṭṭhapāla, kassaci dukkhassa jānāsi.

mn82:7.8.pli: (…) Maraṇenapi te mayaṃ akāmakā vinā bhavissāma.
mn82:7.8.eng: Even when you die we will lose you against our wishes.

mn82:7.9.pli: Kiṃ pana mayaṃ taṃ jīvantaṃ anujānissāma agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāyā”ti?
mn82:7.9.eng: So how can we allow you to go forth while you’re still alive?”

mn82:7.11.pli: tatiyampi kho raṭṭhapālo kulaputto mātāpitaro etadavoca:
mn82:7.11.eng: and a third time, Raṭṭhapāla asked his parents for permission, but got the same reply.

mn82:7.12.pli: “ammatātā, yathā yathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, nayidaṃ sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ ekantaparisuddhaṃ saṅkhalikhitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carituṃ.

mn82:7.13.pli: Icchāmahaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajituṃ.

mn82:7.15.pli: Tatiyampi kho raṭṭhapālassa kulaputtassa mātāpitaro raṭṭhapālaṃ kulaputtaṃ etadavocuṃ:

mn82:7.16.pli: “tvaṃ khosi, tāta raṭṭhapāla, amhākaṃ ekaputtako piyo manāpo sukhedhito sukhaparibhato.

mn82:7.17.pli: Na tvaṃ, tāta raṭṭhapāla, kassaci dukkhassa jānāsi.

mn82:7.18.pli: Maraṇenapi te mayaṃ akāmakā vinā bhavissāma.

mn82:7.19.pli: Kiṃ pana mayaṃ taṃ jīvantaṃ anujānissāma agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāyā”ti?

mn82:7.21.pli: “na maṃ mātāpitaro anujānanti agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāyā”ti tattheva anantarahitāya bhūmiyā nipajji:
mn82:7.21.eng: “My parents don’t allow me to go forth.” He laid down right there on the bare ground, saying,
mn82:7.21.comm: A similar method was employed by Bhaddā Kuṇḍalakesā, according to the commentary to Thig 5.9. She lay face down until her parents allowed her to marry the man she desired, who was, unfortunately, a convicted criminal. The marriage did not end well, but she persevered and ultimately triumphed.

mn82:7.22.eng: “I’ll either die right here or go forth.”

mn82:7.23.pli: Atha kho raṭṭhapālo kulaputto ekampi bhattaṃ na bhuñji, dvepi bhattāni na bhuñji, tīṇipi bhattāni na bhuñji, cattāripi bhattāni na bhuñji, pañcapi bhattāni na bhuñji, chapi bhattāni na bhuñji, sattapi bhattāni na bhuñji.
mn82:7.23.eng: And he refused to eat, up to the seventh meal.

mn82:8.1.pli: Atha kho raṭṭhapālassa kulaputtassa mātāpitaro raṭṭhapālaṃ kulaputtaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn82:8.1.eng: Then Raṭṭhapāla’s parents said to him,

mn82:8.2.pli: “tvaṃ khosi, tāta raṭṭhapāla, amhākaṃ ekaputtako piyo manāpo sukhedhito sukhaparibhato.
mn82:8.2.eng: “Dear Raṭṭhapāla, you’re our only child. You’re dear to us and we love you. You’re dainty and raised in comfort.

mn82:8.3.pli: Na tvaṃ, tāta raṭṭhapāla, kassaci, dukkhassa jānāsi.

mn82:8.4.pli: Maraṇenapi te mayaṃ akāmakā vinā bhavissāma.
mn82:8.4.eng: When you die we will lose you against our wishes.

mn82:8.5.pli: Kiṃ pana mayaṃ taṃ jīvantaṃ anujānissāma agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya.
mn82:8.5.eng: So how can we allow you to go forth from lay life to homelessness while you’re still living?

mn82:8.6.pli: Uṭṭhehi, tāta raṭṭhapāla, bhuñja ca piva ca paricārehi ca;
mn82:8.6.eng: Get up, Raṭṭhapāla! Eat, drink, and amuse yourself.

mn82:8.7.pli: bhuñjanto pivanto paricārento kāme paribhuñjanto puññāni karonto abhiramassu.
mn82:8.7.eng: While enjoying sensual pleasures, delight in making merit.

mn82:8.8.pli: Na taṃ mayaṃ anujānāma agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya.
mn82:8.8.eng: We don’t allow you to go forth.

mn82:8.9.pli: Maraṇenapi te mayaṃ akāmakā vinā bhavissāma.
mn82:8.9.eng: When you die we will lose you against our wishes.

mn82:8.10.pli: Kiṃ pana mayaṃ taṃ jīvantaṃ anujānissāma agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāyā”ti?
mn82:8.10.eng: So how can we allow you to go forth while you’re still alive?”

mn82:8.11.pli: Evaṃ vutte, raṭṭhapālo kulaputto tuṇhī ahosi.
mn82:8.11.eng: When they said this, Raṭṭhapāla kept silent.

mn82:8.12.pli: Dutiyampi kho raṭṭhapālassa kulaputtassa mātāpitaro raṭṭhapālaṃ kulaputtaṃ etadavocuṃ …pe…

mn82:8.13.pli: dutiyampi kho raṭṭhapālo kulaputto tuṇhī ahosi.

mn82:8.14.pli: Tatiyampi kho raṭṭhapālassa kulaputtassa mātāpitaro raṭṭhapālaṃ kulaputtaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn82:8.14.eng: and a third time, Raṭṭhapāla’s parents made the same request.

mn82:8.15.pli: “tvaṃ khosi, tāta raṭṭhapāla, amhākaṃ ekaputtako piyo manāpo sukhedhito sukhaparibhato.

mn82:8.16.pli: Na tvaṃ, tāta raṭṭhapāla, kassaci dukkhassa jānāsi.

mn82:8.17.pli: Maraṇenapi te mayaṃ akāmakā vinā bhavissāma, kiṃ pana mayaṃ taṃ jīvantaṃ anujānissāma agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya.

mn82:8.18.pli: Uṭṭhehi, tāta raṭṭhapāla, bhuñja ca piva ca paricārehi ca;

mn82:8.19.pli: bhuñjanto pivanto paricārento kāme paribhuñjanto puññāni karonto abhiramassu.

mn82:8.20.pli: Na taṃ mayaṃ anujānāma agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya.

mn82:8.21.pli: Maraṇenapi te mayaṃ akāmakā vinā bhavissāma.

mn82:8.22.pli: Kiṃ pana mayaṃ taṃ jīvantaṃ anujānissāma agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāyā”ti?

mn82:9.1.pli: Tatiyampi kho raṭṭhapālo kulaputto tuṇhī ahosi.
mn82:9.1.eng: And for a third time, Raṭṭhapāla kept silent. Raṭṭhapāla’s parents then went to see his friends. They told them of the situation and asked for their help.

mn82:10.1.pli: Atha kho raṭṭhapālassa kulaputtassa sahāyakā yena raṭṭhapālo kulaputto tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā raṭṭhapālaṃ kulaputtaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn82:10.1.eng: Then Raṭṭhapāla’s friends went to him and said,

mn82:10.2.pli: “tvaṃ khosi, samma raṭṭhapāla, mātāpitūnaṃ ekaputtako piyo manāpo sukhedhito sukhaparibhato.
mn82:10.2.eng: “Our friend Raṭṭhapāla, you are your parents’ only child. You’re dear to them and they love you. You’re dainty and raised in comfort.

mn82:10.3.pli: Na tvaṃ, samma raṭṭhapāla, kassaci dukkhassa jānāsi.

mn82:10.4.pli: Maraṇenapi te mātāpitaro akāmakā vinā bhavissanti.
mn82:10.4.eng: When you die your parents will lose you against their wishes.

mn82:10.5.pli: Kiṃ pana te taṃ jīvantaṃ anujānissanti agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya.
mn82:10.5.eng: So how can they allow you to go forth while you’re still alive?

mn82:10.6.pli: Uṭṭhehi, samma raṭṭhapāla, bhuñja ca piva ca paricārehi ca;
mn82:10.6.eng: Get up, Raṭṭhapāla! Eat, drink, and amuse yourself.

mn82:10.7.pli: bhuñjanto pivanto paricārento kāme paribhuñjanto puññāni karonto abhiramassu.
mn82:10.7.eng: While enjoying sensual pleasures, delight in making merit.

mn82:10.8.pli: Na taṃ mātāpitaro anujānissanti agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya.
mn82:10.8.eng: Your parents will not allow you to go forth.

mn82:10.9.pli: Maraṇenapi te mātāpitaro akāmakā vinā bhavissanti.
mn82:10.9.eng: Even when you die your parents will lose you against their wishes.

mn82:10.10.pli: Kiṃ pana te taṃ jīvantaṃ anujānissanti agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāyā”ti?
mn82:10.10.eng: So how can they allow you to go forth while you’re still alive?”

mn82:10.11.pli: Evaṃ vutte, raṭṭhapālo kulaputto tuṇhī ahosi.
mn82:10.11.eng: When they said this, Raṭṭhapāla kept silent.

mn82:10.13.pli: tatiyampi kho raṭṭhapālassa kulaputtassa sahāyakā raṭṭhapālaṃ kulaputtaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn82:10.13.eng: and a third time, Raṭṭhapāla’s friends made the same request.

mn82:10.14.pli: “tvaṃ khosi, samma raṭṭhapāla, mātāpitūnaṃ ekaputtako piyo manāpo sukhedhito sukhaparibhato, na tvaṃ, samma raṭṭhapāla, kassaci dukkhassa jānāsi, maraṇenapi te mātāpitaro akāmakā vinā bhavissanti.

mn82:10.15.pli: Kiṃ pana te taṃ jīvantaṃ anujānissanti agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya?

mn82:10.16.pli: Uṭṭhehi, samma raṭṭhapāla, bhuñja ca piva ca paricārehi ca, bhuñjanto pivanto paricārento kāme paribhuñjanto puññāni karonto abhiramassu.

mn82:10.17.pli: Na taṃ mātāpitaro anujānissanti agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya, maraṇenapi te mātāpitaro akāmakā vinā bhavissanti.

mn82:10.18.pli: Kiṃ pana te taṃ jīvantaṃ anujānissanti agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāyā”ti?

mn82:10.19.pli: Tatiyampi kho raṭṭhapālo kulaputto tuṇhī ahosi.
mn82:10.19.eng: And for a third time, Raṭṭhapāla kept silent.

mn82:11.1.pli: Atha kho raṭṭhapālassa kulaputtassa sahāyakā yena raṭṭhapālassa kulaputtassa mātāpitaro tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā raṭṭhapālassa kulaputtassa mātāpitaro etadavocuṃ:
mn82:11.1.eng: Then Raṭṭhapāla’s friends went to his parents and said,

mn82:11.2.pli: “ammatātā, eso raṭṭhapālo kulaputto tattheva anantarahitāya bhūmiyā nipanno:
mn82:11.2.eng: “Mum and dad, Raṭṭhapāla is lying there on the bare ground saying:

mn82:11.3.eng: ‘I’ll either die right here or go forth.’

mn82:11.4.pli: Sace tumhe raṭṭhapālaṃ kulaputtaṃ nānujānissatha agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya, tattheva maraṇaṃ āgamissati.
mn82:11.4.eng: If you don’t allow him to go forth, he’ll die there.

mn82:11.5.pli: Sace pana tumhe raṭṭhapālaṃ kulaputtaṃ anujānissatha agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya, pabbajitampi naṃ dakkhissatha.
mn82:11.5.eng: But if you do allow him to go forth, you’ll see him again afterwards.

mn82:11.6.pli: Sace raṭṭhapālo kulaputto nābhiramissati agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya, kā tassa aññā gati bhavissati? Idheva paccāgamissati.
mn82:11.6.eng: And if he doesn’t enjoy the renunciate life, where else will he have to go? He’ll come right back here.

mn82:11.7.pli: Anujānātha raṭṭhapālaṃ kulaputtaṃ agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāyā”ti.
mn82:11.7.eng: Please give Raṭṭhapāla permission to go forth.”

mn82:11.8.pli: “Anujānāma, tātā, raṭṭhapālaṃ kulaputtaṃ agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya.
mn82:11.8.eng: “Then, dears, we give Raṭṭhapāla permission to go forth.

mn82:11.9.eng: But once gone forth he must visit his parents.”

mn82:11.10.pli: Atha kho raṭṭhapālassa kulaputtassa sahāyakā yena raṭṭhapālo kulaputto tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā raṭṭhapālaṃ kulaputtaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn82:11.10.eng: Then Raṭṭhapāla’s friends went to him and said,

mn82:11.11.pli: “uṭṭhehi, samma raṭṭhapāla, anuññātosi mātāpitūhi agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya.
mn82:11.11.eng: “Get up, Raṭṭhapāla! Your parents have given you permission to go forth from lay life to homelessness.

mn82:11.12.pli: Pabbajitena ca pana te mātāpitaro uddassetabbā”ti.
mn82:11.12.eng: But once gone forth you must visit your parents.”

mn82:12.1.pli: Atha kho raṭṭhapālo kulaputto uṭṭhahitvā balaṃ gāhetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho raṭṭhapālo kulaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn82:12.1.eng: Raṭṭhapāla got up and regained his strength. He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

mn82:12.2.pli: “anuññāto ahaṃ, bhante, mātāpitūhi agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajjāya.
mn82:12.2.eng: “Sir, I have my parents’ permission to go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

mn82:12.3.eng: May the Buddha please give me the going forth.”

mn82:13.1.pli: Alattha kho raṭṭhapālo kulaputto bhagavato santike pabbajjaṃ, alattha upasampadaṃ.
mn82:13.1.eng: And Raṭṭhapāla received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.

mn82:13.2.pli: Atha kho bhagavā acirūpasampanne āyasmante raṭṭhapāle aḍḍhamāsupasampanne thullakoṭṭhike yathābhirantaṃ viharitvā yena sāvatthi tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
mn82:13.2.eng: Not long after Venerable Raṭṭhapāla’s ordination, a fortnight later, the Buddha—having stayed in Thullakoṭṭhika as long as he pleased—set out for Sāvatthī.

mn82:13.3.pli: Anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena sāvatthi tadavasari.
mn82:13.3.eng: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Sāvatthī,

mn82:13.4.pli: Tatra sudaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
mn82:13.4.eng: where he stayed in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

mn82:14.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
mn82:14.1.eng: Then Venerable Raṭṭhapāla, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
mn82:14.1.comm: While the conventional phrase “soon” (nacirasseva) is used, the commentary says it was twelve years, which would explain why his family did not immediately recognize him.

mn82:14.2.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
mn82:14.2.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

mn82:14.3.pli: Aññataro kho panāyasmā raṭṭhapālo arahataṃ ahosi.
mn82:14.3.eng: And Venerable Raṭṭhapāla became one of the perfected.

mn82:15.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn82:15.1.eng: Then he went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

mn82:15.2.pli: “icchāmahaṃ, bhante, mātāpitaro uddassetuṃ, sace maṃ bhagavā anujānātī”ti.
mn82:15.2.eng: “Sir, I would like to visit my parents, if the Buddha allows it.”

mn82:15.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa cetasā ceto paricca manasākāsi.
mn82:15.3.eng: Then the Buddha focused on encompassing Raṭṭhapāla’s mind.

mn82:15.5.pli: “abhabbo kho raṭṭhapālo kulaputto sikkhaṃ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattitun”ti, atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṃ raṭṭhapālaṃ etadavoca:
mn82:15.5.eng: it was impossible for Raṭṭhapāla to resign the training and return to a lesser life, he said,

mn82:16.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā senāsanaṃ saṃsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena thullakoṭṭhikaṃ tena cārikaṃ pakkāmi.
mn82:16.1.eng: And then Raṭṭhapāla got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Thullakoṭṭhika.

mn82:16.2.pli: Anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena thullakoṭṭhiko tadavasari.
mn82:16.2.eng: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Thullakoṭṭhika,

mn82:16.3.pli: Tatra sudaṃ āyasmā raṭṭhapālo thullakoṭṭhike viharati rañño korabyassa migacīre.
mn82:16.3.eng: where he stayed in King Koravya’s deer range.

mn82:16.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya thullakoṭṭhikaṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
mn82:16.4.eng: Then Raṭṭhapāla robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Thullakoṭṭhika for alms.

mn82:16.5.pli: Thullakoṭṭhike sapadānaṃ piṇḍāya caramāno yena sakapitu nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami.
mn82:16.5.eng: Wandering indiscriminately for almsfood, he approached his own father’s house.

mn82:17.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitā majjhimāya dvārasālāya ullikhāpeti.
mn82:17.1.eng: Now at that time Raṭṭhapāla’s father was having his hair dressed in the hall of the middle gate.
mn82:17.1.comm: This is a sign of the dandified life expected of Raṭṭhapāla. Hairstyles for upper class men of the time were quite fancy, or at least they are depicted so in the early sculptures at Sanchi.

mn82:17.2.pli: Addasā kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitā āyasmantaṃ raṭṭhapālaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
mn82:17.2.eng: He saw Raṭṭhapāla coming off in the distance

mn82:17.4.pli: “imehi muṇḍakehi samaṇakehi amhākaṃ ekaputtako piyo manāpo pabbājito”ti.
mn82:17.4.eng: “Our dear and beloved only son was made to go forth by these shavelings, these fake ascetics!”

mn82:17.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo sakapitu nivesane neva dānaṃ alattha na paccakkhānaṃ;
mn82:17.5.eng: And at his own father’s home Raṭṭhapāla received neither alms nor a polite refusal,

mn82:18.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa ñātidāsī ābhidosikaṃ kummāsaṃ chaḍḍetukāmā hoti.
mn82:18.1.eng: Now at that time a family bondservant wanted to throw away the previous night’s porridge.

mn82:18.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo taṃ ñātidāsiṃ etadavoca:

mn82:18.3.pli: “sacetaṃ, bhagini, chaḍḍanīyadhammaṃ, idha me patte ākirā”ti.
mn82:18.3.eng: “If that’s to be thrown away, sister, pour it here in my bowl.”

mn82:18.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa ñātidāsī taṃ ābhidosikaṃ kummāsaṃ āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa patte ākirantī hatthānañca pādānañca sarassa ca nimittaṃ aggahesi.
mn82:18.4.eng: As she was pouring the porridge into his bowl, she recognized the features of his hands, feet, and voice.
mn82:18.4.comm: This detail is remarkably similar to the Odyssey 19:361–475, where due to the marks on his feet, the maidservant Eurycleia recognizes Odysseus on his return even though his own wife did not.

mn82:18.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa ñātidāsī yenāyasmato raṭṭhapālassa mātā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa mātaraṃ etadavoca:
mn82:18.5.eng: She then went to his mother and said,

mn82:18.8.pli: “Sace, je, saccaṃ bhaṇasi, adāsiṃ taṃ karomī”ti.
mn82:18.8.eng: “If you speak the truth, wench, I’ll make you a free woman!”

mn82:18.9.pli: Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa mātā yenāyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitaraṃ etadavoca:
mn82:18.9.eng: Then Raṭṭhapāla’s mother went to his father and said,

mn82:18.11.eng: It seems our son Raṭṭhapāla has arrived.”

mn82:19.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā raṭṭhapālo taṃ ābhidosikaṃ kummāsaṃ aññataraṃ kuṭṭamūlaṃ nissāya paribhuñjati.
mn82:19.1.eng: Now at that time Raṭṭhapāla was eating last night’s porridge by a wall.

mn82:19.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitā yenāyasmā raṭṭhapālo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ raṭṭhapālaṃ etadavoca:
mn82:19.2.eng: Then Raṭṭhapāla’s father went up to him and said,

mn82:19.3.pli: “atthi nāma, tāta raṭṭhapāla, ābhidosikaṃ kummāsaṃ paribhuñjissasi?
mn82:19.3.eng: “Dear Raṭṭhapāla! How can you be eating last night’s porridge?
mn82:19.3.comm: The same syntax recurs at AN 5.166:11.2, where it is clear the future tense expresses indignation rather than future time.

mn82:19.4.pli: Nanu, tāta raṭṭhapāla, sakaṃ gehaṃ gantabban”ti?
mn82:19.4.eng: Why not go to your own home?”
mn82:19.4.comm: In the Vinaya, the exchange between Raṭṭhapāla and his father is expressed in verse (Bu Ss 6:1.5.1).

mn82:19.5.pli: “Kuto no, gahapati, amhākaṃ gehaṃ agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajitānaṃ?
mn82:19.5.eng: “Householder, how could those of us who have gone forth from the lay life to homelessness have a house?

mn82:19.7.pli: Agamamha kho te, gahapati, gehaṃ, tattha neva dānaṃ alatthamha na paccakkhānaṃ;
mn82:19.7.eng: I came to your house, but there I received neither alms nor a polite refusal,

mn82:19.9.eng: “Come, dear Raṭṭhapāla, let’s go to the house.”

mn82:19.10.eng: “Enough, householder. My meal is finished for today.”

mn82:19.11.pli: “Tena hi, tāta raṭṭhapāla, adhivāsehi svātanāya bhattan”ti.
mn82:19.11.eng: “Well then, dear Raṭṭhapāla, please accept tomorrow’s meal from me.”

mn82:20.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitā āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa adhivāsanaṃ viditvā yena sakaṃ nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā mahantaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇassa puñjaṃ kārāpetvā kilañjehi paṭicchādetvā āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa purāṇadutiyikā āmantesi:
mn82:20.1.eng: Then, knowing that Raṭṭhapāla had consented, his father went back to his own house. He made a heap of gold, both coined and uncoined, and hid it under mats. Then he addressed Raṭṭhapāla’s former wives,

mn82:20.2.pli: “etha tumhe, vadhuyo, yena alaṅkārena alaṅkatā pubbe raṭṭhapālassa kulaputtassa piyā hotha manāpā tena alaṅkārena alaṅkarothā”ti.
mn82:20.2.eng: “Please, daughters-in-law, adorn yourselves in the way that our son Raṭṭhapāla found you most adorable.”

mn82:21.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitā tassā rattiyā accayena sake nivesane paṇītaṃ khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyādāpetvā āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa kālaṃ ārocesi:
mn82:21.1.eng: And when the night had passed Raṭṭhapāla’s father had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own home, and announced the time to the Venerable Raṭṭhapāla, saying,

mn82:21.2.eng: “Sir, it’s time. The meal is ready.”

mn82:22.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena sakapitu nivesanaṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi. Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitā taṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇassa puñjaṃ vivarāpetvā āyasmantaṃ raṭṭhapālaṃ etadavoca:
mn82:22.1.eng: Then Raṭṭhapāla robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to his father’s home, and sat down on the seat spread out. Raṭṭhapāla’s father, revealing the heap of gold, both coined and uncoined, said to him,

mn82:22.2.pli: “idaṃ te, tāta raṭṭhapāla, mātu mattikaṃ dhanaṃ, aññaṃ pettikaṃ, aññaṃ pitāmahaṃ.
mn82:22.2.eng: “Dear Raṭṭhapāla, this is your maternal fortune. There’s another paternal fortune, and an ancestral one.

mn82:22.3.pli: Sakkā, tāta raṭṭhapāla, bhoge ca bhuñjituṃ puññāni ca kātuṃ.
mn82:22.3.eng: You can both enjoy your wealth and make merit.

mn82:22.4.pli: Ehi tvaṃ, tāta raṭṭhapāla, hīnāyāvattitvā bhoge ca bhuñjassu puññāni ca karohī”ti.
mn82:22.4.eng: Come, return to a lesser life, enjoy wealth, and make merit!”

mn82:22.5.pli: “Sace me tvaṃ, gahapati, vacanaṃ kareyyāsi, imaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇassa puñjaṃ sakaṭe āropetvā nibbāhāpetvā majjhegaṅgāya nadiyā sote opilāpeyyāsi.
mn82:22.5.eng: “If you’d follow my advice, householder, you’d have this heap of gold, both coined and uncoined, loaded on a cart and carried away to be dumped in the middle of the Ganges river.

mn82:22.7.pli: Ye uppajjissanti hi te, gahapati, tatonidānaṃ sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti.
mn82:22.7.eng: Because this will bring you nothing but sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.”

mn82:23.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa purāṇadutiyikā paccekaṃ pādesu gahetvā āyasmantaṃ raṭṭhapālaṃ etadavocuṃ:
mn82:23.1.eng: Then Raṭṭhapāla’s former wives each clasped his feet and said,

mn82:23.2.pli: “kīdisā nāma tā, ayyaputta, accharāyo yāsaṃ tvaṃ hetu brahmacariyaṃ carasī”ti?
mn82:23.2.eng: “What are they like, master, the nymphs for whom you lead the spiritual life?”

mn82:23.3.pli: “Na kho mayaṃ, bhaginī, accharānaṃ hetu brahmacariyaṃ carāmā”ti.
mn82:23.3.eng: “Sisters, I don’t lead the spiritual life for the sake of nymphs.”
mn82:23.3.comm: Raṭṭhapāla refers to his former wives as sisters, an indication that he sees them in accordance with the advice in SN 35.127:1.6, to regard women of one’s one age as a sister. Notably, he has already used the same respectful term when addressing the household maid, whereas his mother uses the disrespectful “wench” (je).

mn82:23.4.pli: “Bhaginivādena no ayyaputto raṭṭhapālo samudācaratī”ti tā tattheva mucchitā papatiṃsu.
mn82:23.4.eng: Saying, “Our master Raṭṭhapāla addresses us as sisters!” they fainted right away.

mn82:24.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo pitaraṃ etadavoca:
mn82:24.1.eng: Then Raṭṭhapāla said to his father,

mn82:24.2.eng: “If there is food to be given, householder, please give it.

mn82:24.4.eng: “Eat, dear Raṭṭhapāla. The meal is ready.”

mn82:24.5.pli: Atha kho āyasmato raṭṭhapālassa pitā āyasmantaṃ raṭṭhapālaṃ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
mn82:24.5.eng: Then Raṭṭhapāla’s father served and satisfied Venerable Raṭṭhapāla with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.

mn82:24.6.pli: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo bhuttāvī onītapattapāṇī ṭhitakova imā gāthā abhāsi:
mn82:24.6.eng: When he had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, he spoke this verse while standing right there:

mn82:25.1.comm: The following verses are also found in Raṭṭhapāla’s verses at Thag 16.4.

mn82:25.4.eng: in which nothing lasts at all.

mn82:25.7.eng: it is bones encased in skin,

mn82:25.11.eng: may be enough to beguile a fool,

mn82:25.12.eng: but not a seeker of the far shore.

mn82:25.15.eng: may be enough to beguile a fool,

mn82:25.16.eng: but not a seeker of the far shore.

mn82:25.18.eng: like a freshly painted makeup box

mn82:25.19.eng: may be enough to beguile a fool,

mn82:25.20.eng: but not a seeker of the far shore.

mn82:25.22.eng: but the deer didn’t spring the trap.

mn82:25.23.eng: I’ve eaten the bait and now I go,

mn82:26.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā raṭṭhapālo ṭhitakova imā gāthā bhāsitvā yena rañño korabyassa migacīraṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṃ nisīdi.
mn82:26.1.eng: Then Raṭṭhapāla, having spoke this verse while standing, went to King Koravya’s deer range and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.

mn82:27.1.pli: Atha kho rājā korabyo migavaṃ āmantesi:
mn82:27.1.eng: Then King Koravya addressed his gamekeeper,
mn82:27.1.comm: Koravya (Sanskrit kauravya or kaurava) is the conventional name for descendants of the legendary Kuru, founding king of the Kurus.

mn82:27.2.eng: “My good gamekeeper, tidy up the park of the deer range.

mn82:27.3.eng: We will go to see the scenery.”

mn82:27.4.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho migavo rañño korabyassa paṭissutvā migacīraṃ sodhento addasa āyasmantaṃ raṭṭhapālaṃ aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṃ nisinnaṃ.
mn82:27.4.eng: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied the gamekeeper. While tidying the deer range he saw Raṭṭhapāla sitting in meditation.

mn82:27.5.pli: Disvāna yena rājā korabyo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā rājānaṃ korabyaṃ etadavoca:
mn82:27.5.eng: Seeing this, he went to the king, and said,

mn82:27.7.pli: Atthi cettha raṭṭhapālo nāma kulaputto imasmiṃyeva thullakoṭṭhike aggakulassa putto yassa tvaṃ abhiṇhaṃ kittayamāno ahosi, so aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle divāvihāraṃ nisinno”ti.
mn82:27.7.eng: And the gentleman named Raṭṭhapāla, the son of the leading clan in Thullakoṭṭhika, of whom you have often spoken highly, is meditating there at the root of a tree.”

mn82:27.8.pli: “Tena hi, samma migava, alaṃ dānajja uyyānabhūmiyā.
mn82:27.8.eng: “Well then, my good gamekeeper, that’s enough of the park for today.

mn82:27.9.pli: Tameva dāni mayaṃ bhavantaṃ raṭṭhapālaṃ payirupāsissāmā”ti.
mn82:27.9.eng: Now I shall pay homage to the worthy Raṭṭhapāla.”

mn82:28.1.pli: Atha kho rājā korabyo “yaṃ tattha khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyaṃ paṭiyattaṃ taṃ sabbaṃ vissajjethā”ti vatvā bhadrāni bhadrāni yānāni yojāpetvā bhadraṃ yānaṃ abhiruhitvā bhadrehi bhadrehi yānehi thullakoṭṭhikamhā niyyāsi mahaccarājānubhāvena āyasmantaṃ raṭṭhapālaṃ dassanāya.
mn82:28.1.eng: And then King Koravya said, “Give away the fresh and cooked foods that have been prepared there.” He had the finest carriages harnessed. Then he mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out in full royal pomp from Thullakoṭṭhika to see Raṭṭhapāla.

mn82:28.2.pli: Yāvatikā yānassa bhūmi yānena gantvā yānā paccorohitvā pattikova ussaṭāya ussaṭāya parisāya yenāyasmā raṭṭhapālo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā raṭṭhapālena saddhiṃ sammodi. Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho rājā korabyo āyasmantaṃ raṭṭhapālaṃ etadavoca:
mn82:28.2.eng: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached Raṭṭhapāla on foot, together with a group of eminent officials. They exchanged greetings, and, when the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side and said to Raṭṭhapāla:

mn82:28.3.eng: “Here, worthy Raṭṭhapāla, sit on this elephant rug.”

mn82:28.4.eng: “Enough, great king, you sit on it.

mn82:28.5.eng: I’m sitting on my own seat.”

mn82:28.6.pli: Nisīdi rājā korabyo paññatte āsane. Nisajja kho rājā korabyo āyasmantaṃ raṭṭhapālaṃ etadavoca:
mn82:28.6.eng: So the king sat down on the seat spread out, and said:

mn82:29.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, bho raṭṭhapāla, pārijuññāni yehi pārijuññehi samannāgatā idhekacce kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti.
mn82:29.1.eng: “Worthy Raṭṭhapāla, there are these four kinds of decay. Because of these, some people shave off their hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

mn82:29.3.eng: Decay due to old age, decay due to sickness, decay of wealth, and decay of relatives.

mn82:30.1.eng: And what is decay due to old age?

mn82:30.2.pli: Idha, bho raṭṭhapāla, ekacco jiṇṇo hoti vuḍḍho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto.
mn82:30.2.eng: It’s when someone is old, elderly, and senior, advanced in years, and has reached the final stage of life.

mn82:30.4.pli: ‘ahaṃ khomhi etarahi jiṇṇo vuḍḍho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto.
mn82:30.4.eng: ‘I’m now old, elderly, and senior. I’m advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life.

mn82:30.5.pli: Na kho pana mayā sukaraṃ anadhigataṃ vā bhogaṃ adhigantuṃ adhigataṃ vā bhogaṃ phātiṃ kātuṃ.
mn82:30.5.eng: It’s not easy for me to acquire more wealth or to increase the wealth I’ve already acquired.

mn82:30.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyan’ti.
mn82:30.6.eng: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

mn82:30.7.pli: So tena jarāpārijuññena samannāgato kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
mn82:30.7.eng: So because of that decay due to old age they go forth.

mn82:30.8.eng: This is called decay due to old age.

mn82:30.9.pli: Bhavaṃ kho pana raṭṭhapālo etarahi daharo yuvā susukāḷakeso bhadrena yobbanena samannāgato paṭhamena vayasā.
mn82:30.9.eng: But worthy Raṭṭhapāla is now a youth, young, with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life.
mn82:30.9.comm: While Raṭṭhapāla’s age is not given, he seems quite young when he went forth. He addresses his parents with the familiar “mum and dad”; permission of his parents is required; his friends play a major role influencing his decisions; and he lies on the ground refusing to move until he gets what he wants from his parents. All this sounds like a teenager. True, he was married, but such marriages could be arranged young. And now here, twelve years later according to the commentary, he is still a young man.

mn82:30.10.eng: You have no decay due to old age.

mn82:30.11.pli: Kiṃ bhavaṃ raṭṭhapālo ñatvā vā disvā vā sutvā vā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito?
mn82:30.11.eng: So what did you know or see or hear that made you go forth?

mn82:31.1.eng: And what is decay due to sickness?

mn82:31.2.pli: Idha, bho raṭṭhapāla, ekacco ābādhiko hoti dukkhito bāḷhagilāno.
mn82:31.2.eng: It’s when someone is sick, suffering, gravely ill.

mn82:31.5.pli: Na kho pana mayā sukaraṃ anadhigataṃ vā bhogaṃ adhigantuṃ adhigataṃ vā bhogaṃ phātiṃ kātuṃ.
mn82:31.5.eng: It’s not easy for me to acquire more wealth or to increase the wealth I’ve already acquired.

mn82:31.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyan’ti.
mn82:31.6.eng: Why don’t I go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

mn82:31.7.pli: So tena byādhipārijuññena samannāgato kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
mn82:31.7.eng: So because of that decay due to sickness they go forth.

mn82:31.8.eng: This is called decay due to sickness.

mn82:31.9.pli: Bhavaṃ kho pana raṭṭhapālo etarahi appābādho appātaṅko samavepākiniyā gahaṇiyā samannāgato nātisītāya nāccuṇhāya.
mn82:31.9.eng: But worthy Raṭṭhapāla is now rarely ill or unwell. Your stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold.

mn82:31.10.eng: You have no decay due to sickness.

mn82:31.11.pli: Kiṃ bhavaṃ raṭṭhapālo ñatvā vā disvā vā sutvā vā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito?
mn82:31.11.eng: So what did you know or see or hear that made you go forth?

mn82:32.1.eng: And what is decay of wealth?

mn82:32.2.pli: Idha, bho raṭṭhapāla, ekacco aḍḍho hoti mahaddhano mahābhogo.
mn82:32.2.eng: It’s when someone is rich, affluent, and wealthy.

mn82:32.3.pli: Tassa te bhogā anupubbena parikkhayaṃ gacchanti.
mn82:32.3.eng: But gradually their wealth dwindles away.

mn82:32.5.pli: ‘ahaṃ kho pubbe aḍḍho ahosiṃ mahaddhano mahābhogo.
mn82:32.5.eng: ‘I used to be rich, affluent, and wealthy.

mn82:32.6.pli: Tassa me te bhogā anupubbena parikkhayaṃ gatā.
mn82:32.6.eng: But gradually my wealth has dwindled away.

mn82:32.7.pli: Na kho pana mayā sukaraṃ anadhigataṃ vā bhogaṃ adhigantuṃ adhigataṃ vā bhogaṃ phātiṃ kātuṃ.
mn82:32.7.eng: It’s not easy for me to acquire more wealth or to increase the wealth I’ve already acquired.

mn82:32.8.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyan’ti.
mn82:32.8.eng: Why don’t I go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

mn82:32.9.pli: So tena bhogapārijuññena samannāgato kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
mn82:32.9.eng: So because of that decay of wealth they go forth.

mn82:32.10.eng: This is called decay of wealth.

mn82:32.11.pli: Bhavaṃ kho pana raṭṭhapālo imasmiṃyeva thullakoṭṭhike aggakulassa putto.
mn82:32.11.eng: But worthy Raṭṭhapāla is the son of the leading clan here in Thullakoṭṭhika.

mn82:32.12.eng: You have no decay of wealth.

mn82:32.13.pli: Kiṃ bhavaṃ raṭṭhapālo ñatvā vā disvā vā sutvā vā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito?
mn82:32.13.eng: So what did you know or see or hear that made you go forth?

mn82:33.1.eng: And what is decay of relatives?

mn82:33.2.pli: Idha, bho raṭṭhapāla, ekaccassa bahū honti mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā.
mn82:33.2.eng: It’s when someone has many friends and colleagues, relatives and kin.

mn82:33.3.pli: Tassa te ñātakā anupubbena parikkhayaṃ gacchanti.
mn82:33.3.eng: But gradually their relatives dwindle away.

mn82:33.5.pli: ‘mamaṃ kho pubbe bahū ahesuṃ mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā.
mn82:33.5.eng: ‘I used to have many friends and colleagues, relatives and kin.

mn82:33.6.pli: Tassa me te anupubbena parikkhayaṃ gatā.

mn82:33.7.pli: Na kho pana mayā sukaraṃ anadhigataṃ vā bhogaṃ adhigantuṃ adhigataṃ vā bhogaṃ phātiṃ kātuṃ.
mn82:33.7.eng: It’s not easy for me to acquire more wealth or to increase the wealth I’ve already acquired.

mn82:33.8.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyan’ti.
mn82:33.8.eng: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

mn82:33.9.pli: So tena ñātipārijuññena samannāgato kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
mn82:33.9.eng: So because of that decay of relatives they go forth.

mn82:33.10.eng: This is called decay of relatives.

mn82:33.11.pli: Bhoto kho pana raṭṭhapālassa imasmiṃyeva thullakoṭṭhike bahū mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā.
mn82:33.11.eng: But worthy Raṭṭhapāla has many friends and colleagues, relatives and kin right here in Thullakoṭṭhika.

mn82:33.12.eng: You have no decay of relatives.

mn82:33.13.pli: Kiṃ bhavaṃ raṭṭhapālo ñatvā vā disvā vā sutvā vā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito?
mn82:33.13.eng: So what did you know or see or hear that made you go forth?

mn82:34.1.pli: Imāni kho, bho raṭṭhapāla, cattāri pārijuññāni, yehi pārijuññehi samannāgatā idhekacce kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti.
mn82:34.1.eng: There are these four kinds of decay. Because of these, some people shave off their hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

mn82:34.2.eng: Worthy Raṭṭhapāla has none of these.

mn82:34.3.pli: Kiṃ bhavaṃ raṭṭhapālo ñatvā vā disvā vā sutvā vā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito”ti?
mn82:34.3.eng: So what did you know or see or hear that made you go forth?”

mn82:35.1.pli: “Atthi kho, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cattāro dhammuddesā uddiṭṭhā, ye ahaṃ ñatvā ca disvā ca sutvā ca agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.
mn82:35.1.eng: “Great king, the Blessed One who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha has taught these four summaries of the teaching for recitation. It was after knowing and seeing and hearing these that I went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
mn82:35.1.comm: While these four summaries reflect key teachings of the Buddha, they are not found as such in early texts.

mn82:36.1.eng: ‘The world is unstable and swept away.’

mn82:36.2.pli: kho, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena paṭhamo dhammuddeso uddiṭṭho, yamahaṃ ñatvā ca disvā ca sutvā ca agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.

mn82:36.3.eng: ‘The world has no shelter and no savior.’

mn82:36.4.pli: kho, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena dutiyo dhammuddeso uddiṭṭho, yamahaṃ ñatvā ca disvā ca sutvā ca agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.

mn82:36.5.eng: ‘The world has no owner—you must leave it all behind and pass on.’

mn82:36.6.pli: kho, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena tatiyo dhammuddeso uddiṭṭho, yamahaṃ ñatvā ca disvā ca sutvā ca agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.

mn82:36.7.eng: ‘The world is wanting, insatiable, the slave of craving.’

mn82:36.8.pli: kho, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena catuttho dhammuddeso uddiṭṭho, yamahaṃ ñatvā ca disvā ca sutvā ca agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.

mn82:37.1.pli: Ime kho, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena cattāro dhammuddesā uddiṭṭhā, ye ahaṃ ñatvā ca disvā ca sutvā ca agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito”ti.
mn82:37.1.eng: The Blessed One who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha taught these four summaries of the teaching. It was after knowing and seeing and hearing these that I went forth from the lay life to homelessness.”

mn82:38.1.eng: “‘The world is unstable and swept away.’

mn82:38.3.pli: Imassa, bho raṭṭhapāla, bhāsitassa kathaṃ attho daṭṭhabbo”ti?
mn82:38.3.eng: How should I see the meaning of this statement?”

mn82:38.5.pli: tvaṃ vīsativassuddesikopi paṇṇavīsativassuddesikopi hatthismimpi katāvī assasmimpi katāvī rathasmimpi katāvī dhanusmimpi katāvī tharusmimpi katāvī ūrubalī bāhubalī alamatto saṅgāmāvacaro”ti?
mn82:38.5.eng: When you were twenty or twenty-five years of age, were you proficient at riding elephants, horses, and chariots, and at archery and swordsmanship? Were you strong in thigh and arm, capable, and battle-hardened?”
mn82:38.5.comm: For alamatto read alamattho, “capable”.

mn82:38.6.pli: “Ahosiṃ ahaṃ, bho raṭṭhapāla, vīsativassuddesikopi paṇṇavīsativassuddesikopi hatthismimpi katāvī assasmimpi katāvī rathasmimpi katāvī dhanusmimpi katāvī tharusmimpi katāvī ūrubalī bāhubalī alamatto saṅgāmāvacaro.

mn82:38.7.pli: Appekadāhaṃ, bho raṭṭhapāla, iddhimāva maññe na attano balena samasamaṃ samanupassāmī”ti.
mn82:38.7.eng: Sometimes it seems as if I had superpowers then. I don’t see anyone who could have equalled me in strength.”

mn82:38.9.pli: evameva tvaṃ etarahi ūrubalī bāhubalī alamatto saṅgāmāvacaro”ti?
mn82:38.9.eng: These days are you just as strong in thigh and arm, capable, and battle-hardened?”

mn82:38.11.pli: Etarahi jiṇṇo vuḍḍho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto āsītiko me vayo vattati.
mn82:38.11.eng: For now I am old, elderly, and senior, I’m advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life. I am eighty years old.

mn82:38.12.pli: Appekadāhaṃ, bho raṭṭhapāla, ‘idha pādaṃ karissāmī’ti aññeneva pādaṃ karomī”ti.
mn82:38.12.eng: Sometimes I intend to step in one place, but my foot goes somewhere else.”

mn82:38.13.pli: “Idaṃ kho taṃ, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
mn82:38.13.eng: “This is what the Buddha was referring to when he said:

mn82:38.14.eng: ‘The world is unstable and swept away.’”

mn82:38.15.pli: yamahaṃ ñatvā ca disvā ca sutvā ca agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito”ti.

mn82:38.17.pli: Yāva subhāsitañcidaṃ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena:
mn82:38.17.eng: how well said this was by the Buddha.

mn82:38.19.pli: Upaniyyati hi, bho raṭṭhapāla, loko addhuvo.
mn82:38.19.eng: For the world is indeed unstable and swept away.

mn82:39.1.pli: Saṃvijjante kho, bho raṭṭhapāla, imasmiṃ rājakule hatthikāyāpi assakāyāpi rathakāyāpi pattikāyāpi, amhākaṃ āpadāsu pariyodhāya vattissanti.
mn82:39.1.eng: In this royal court you can find divisions of elephants, cavalry, chariots, and infantry. They will serve to defend us from any threats. Yet you said:

mn82:39.2.eng: ‘The world has no shelter and no savior.’

mn82:39.4.pli: Imassa pana, bho raṭṭhapāla, bhāsitassa kathaṃ attho daṭṭhabbo”ti?
mn82:39.4.eng: How should I see the meaning of this statement?”

mn82:39.6.eng: Do you have any chronic ailments?”

mn82:39.8.pli: Appekadā maṃ, bho raṭṭhapāla, mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā parivāretvā ṭhitā honti:
mn82:39.8.eng: Sometimes my friends and colleagues, relatives and kin surround me, thinking:

mn82:39.9.pli: ‘idāni rājā korabyo kālaṃ karissati, idāni rājā korabyo kālaṃ karissatī’”ti.
mn82:39.9.eng: ‘Now the king will die! Now the king will die!’”

mn82:39.11.eng: Can you get your friends and colleagues, relatives and kin to help:

mn82:39.12.pli: ‘āyantu me bhonto mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā, sabbeva santā imaṃ vedanaṃ saṃvibhajatha, yathāhaṃ lahukatarikaṃ vedanaṃ vediyeyyan’ti—
mn82:39.12.eng: ‘Please, my dear friends and colleagues, relatives and kin, all of you here share my pain so that I may feel less pain.’

mn82:39.13.eng: Or must you alone feel that pain?”

mn82:39.14.pli: “Nāhaṃ, bho raṭṭhapāla, labhāmi te mittāmacce ñātisālohite:
mn82:39.14.eng: “I can’t get my friends to share my pain.

mn82:39.15.pli: ‘āyantu me bhonto mittāmaccā ñātisālohitā, sabbeva santā imaṃ vedanaṃ saṃvibhajatha, yathāhaṃ lahukatarikaṃ vedanaṃ vediyeyyan’ti.

mn82:39.16.pli: Atha kho ahameva taṃ vedanaṃ vediyāmī”ti.
mn82:39.16.eng: Rather, I alone must feel it.”

mn82:39.17.pli: “Idaṃ kho taṃ, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
mn82:39.17.eng: “This is what the Buddha was referring to when he said:

mn82:39.18.eng: ‘The world has no shelter and no savior.’”

mn82:39.19.pli: yamahaṃ ñatvā ca disvā ca sutvā ca agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito”ti.

mn82:39.21.pli: Yāva subhāsitaṃ cidaṃ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena:
mn82:39.21.eng: how well said this was by the Buddha.

mn82:39.23.pli: Atāṇo hi, bho raṭṭhapāla, loko anabhissaro.
mn82:39.23.eng: For the world indeed has no shelter and no savior.

mn82:40.1.pli: Saṃvijjati kho, bho raṭṭhapāla, imasmiṃ rājakule pahūtaṃ hiraññasuvaṇṇaṃ bhūmigatañca vehāsagatañca.
mn82:40.1.eng: In this royal court you can find abundant gold, both coined and uncoined, stored above and below ground. Yet you said:

mn82:40.2.eng: ‘The world has no owner—you must leave it all behind and pass on.’

mn82:40.4.pli: Imassa pana, bho raṭṭhapāla, bhāsitassa kathaṃ attho daṭṭhabbo”ti?
mn82:40.4.eng: How should I see the meaning of this statement?”

mn82:40.6.pli: yathā tvaṃ etarahi pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāresi, lacchasi tvaṃ paratthāpi:
mn82:40.6.eng: These days you amuse yourself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation. But is there any way to ensure that in the next life

mn82:40.7.pli: ‘evamevāhaṃ imeheva pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāremī’ti, udāhu aññe imaṃ bhogaṃ paṭipajjissanti, tvaṃ pana yathākammaṃ gamissasī”ti?
mn82:40.7.eng: you will continue to amuse yourself in the same way, supplied and provided with the same five kinds of sensual stimulation? Or will others make use of this property, while you pass on according to your deeds?”

mn82:40.8.pli: “Yathāhaṃ, bho raṭṭhapāla, etarahi pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāremi, nāhaṃ lacchāmi paratthāpi:
mn82:40.8.eng: “There’s no way to ensure that I will continue to amuse myself in the same way.

mn82:40.9.pli: ‘evameva imeheva pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāremī’ti.

mn82:40.10.pli: Atha kho aññe imaṃ bhogaṃ paṭipajjissanti; ahaṃ pana yathākammaṃ gamissāmī”ti.
mn82:40.10.eng: Rather, others will take over this property, while I pass on according to my deeds.”

mn82:40.11.pli: “Idaṃ kho taṃ, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
mn82:40.11.eng: “This is what the Buddha was referring to when he said:

mn82:40.12.eng: ‘The world has no owner—you must leave it all behind and pass on.’”

mn82:40.13.pli: yamahaṃ ñatvā ca disvā ca sutvā ca agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito”ti.

mn82:40.15.pli: Yāva subhāsitaṃ cidaṃ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena:
mn82:40.15.eng: how well said this was by the Buddha.

mn82:40.17.pli: Assako hi, bho raṭṭhapāla, loko sabbaṃ pahāya gamanīyaṃ.
mn82:40.17.eng: For the world indeed has no owner—you must leave it all behind and pass on.

mn82:41.1.eng: You also said this: ‘The world is wanting, insatiable, the slave of craving.’

mn82:41.3.pli: Imassa, bho raṭṭhapāla, bhāsitassa kathaṃ attho daṭṭhabbo”ti?
mn82:41.3.eng: How should I see the meaning of this statement?”

mn82:41.5.eng: Do you reign over the prosperous land of Kuru?”

mn82:41.8.pli: idha puriso āgaccheyya puratthimāya disāya saddhāyiko paccayiko.
mn82:41.8.eng: Suppose a trustworthy and dependable man were to come from the east.

mn82:41.10.pli: ‘yagghe, mahārāja, jāneyyāsi, ahaṃ āgacchāmi puratthimāya disāya?
mn82:41.10.eng: ‘Please great king, you should know this. I come from the east.

mn82:41.11.pli: Tatthaddasaṃ mahantaṃ janapadaṃ iddhañceva phītañca bahujanaṃ ākiṇṇamanussaṃ.
mn82:41.11.eng: There I saw a large country that is successful and prosperous, populous, full of people.

mn82:41.12.pli: Bahū tattha hatthikāyā assakāyā rathakāyā pattikāyā;
mn82:41.12.eng: They have many divisions of elephants, cavalry, chariots, and infantry.

mn82:41.13.eng: And there’s plenty of money and grain,

mn82:41.14.eng: plenty of gold, coined and uncoined, worked and unworked,

mn82:41.15.eng: and plenty of women for the taking.

mn82:41.16.eng: With your current forces you can conquer it.

mn82:41.17.eng: Conquer it, great king!’ What would you do?”

mn82:41.18.eng: “I would conquer it and reign over it.”

mn82:41.20.eng: Suppose a trustworthy and dependable man were to come from the west,

mn82:41.23.comm: This is a rare acknowledgement of the existence of lands over the seas.

mn82:41.24.eng: He’d approach you and say the same thing.

mn82:41.26.pli: Tatthaddasaṃ mahantaṃ janapadaṃ iddhañceva phītañca bahujanaṃ ākiṇṇamanussaṃ.

mn82:41.27.pli: Bahū tattha hatthikāyā assakāyā rathakāyā pattikāyā;

mn82:41.33.eng: “I would conquer it and reign over it.”

mn82:41.34.pli: “Idaṃ kho taṃ, mahārāja, tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
mn82:41.34.eng: “This is what the Buddha was referring to when he said:

mn82:41.35.eng: ‘The world is wanting, insatiable, the slave of craving.’
mn82:41.35.comm: This passage is a counterweight to the ideal of the Wheel-turning Monarch, who “after conquering this land girt by sea, reigns by principle, without rod or sword” (eg. MN 91:5.8). The Wheel-turning Monarch is in turn a Buddhist recasting of the Brahmanical notion of a king who rules by favor of the gods as demonstrated in the horse sacrifice. The idea of a righteous king whom all obey without coercion belongs rightly to legend, while as Raṭṭhapāla so eloquently, not to mention bravely, points out, the very desire to rule is founded on craving.

mn82:41.36.pli: yamahaṃ ñatvā ca disvā ca sutvā ca agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito”ti.
mn82:41.36.eng: And it was after knowing and seeing and hearing this that I went forth from the lay life to homelessness.”

mn82:41.38.pli: Yāva subhāsitañcidaṃ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena:
mn82:41.38.eng: how well said this was by the Buddha.

mn82:41.40.pli: Ūno hi, bho raṭṭhapāla, loko atitto taṇhādāso”ti.
mn82:41.40.eng: For the world is indeed wanting, insatiable, the slave of craving.”

mn82:42.1.eng: This is what Venerable Raṭṭhapāla said.

mn82:42.2.eng: Then he went on to say:

mn82:42.3.eng: “I see rich humans in the world who,

mn82:42.4.eng: because of delusion, give not <j>the wealth they’ve earned.

mn82:42.6.eng: yearning for ever more sensual pleasures.

mn82:42.7.eng: A king who conquered the earth by force,

mn82:42.8.eng: ruling the land from sea to sea,

mn82:42.9.eng: unsatisfied with the near shore of the ocean,

mn82:42.10.eng: would still yearn for the further shore.

mn82:42.11.pli: Rājā ca aññe ca bahū manussā,
mn82:42.11.eng: Not just the king, but others too,

mn82:42.12.eng: reach death not rid of craving.

mn82:42.13.eng: They leave the body still wanting,

mn82:42.14.eng: for in this world sensual pleasures never satisfy.

mn82:42.17.eng: They take out the body wrapped in a shroud,

mn82:42.18.eng: heap up a pyre, and burn it there.

mn82:42.19.eng: It’s poked with stakes while being burnt,

mn82:42.20.eng: in just a single cloth, all wealth gone.

mn82:42.22.eng: can’t help you when you’re dying.

mn82:42.24.eng: while beings fare on according to their deeds.

mn82:42.25.eng: Riches don’t follow you when you die;

mn82:42.26.pli: Puttā ca dārā ca dhanañca raṭṭhaṃ.
mn82:42.26.eng: nor do children, wife, wealth, nor kingdom.

mn82:42.28.eng: nor does wealth banish old age;

mn82:42.29.eng: for the attentive say this life is short,

mn82:42.31.eng: The rich and the poor feel its touch;

mn82:42.32.pli: Bālo ca dhīro ca tatheva phuṭṭho;
mn82:42.32.eng: the fool and the attentive one feel it too.

mn82:42.33.eng: But the fool lies stricken by their own folly,

mn82:42.34.eng: while the attentive one does not tremble at the touch.

mn82:42.35.eng: Therefore wisdom’s much better than wealth,

mn82:42.36.eng: since by wisdom <j>you reach consummation in this life.

mn82:42.37.eng: But if because of delusion <j>you don’t reach consummation,

mn82:42.38.eng: you’ll do evil deeds in life after life.

mn82:42.39.eng: One who enters a womb and the world beyond,

mn82:42.40.eng: will transmigrate from one life to the next.

mn82:42.41.eng: While someone of little wisdom, <j>placing faith in them,

mn82:42.42.eng: also enters a womb and the world beyond.

mn82:42.43.eng: As a bandit caught in a window

mn82:42.44.eng: is punished for his own bad deeds;

mn82:42.45.eng: so after departing, in the world beyond,

mn82:42.46.eng: people are punished for their own bad deeds.

mn82:42.47.eng: Sensual pleasures are diverse, sweet, delightful;

mn82:42.48.eng: appearing in disguise they disturb the mind.
mn82:42.48.comm: Virūparūpena appears at DN 24:1.17.8, Ja 522:18.3, and Ja 526:56.2, where it always has the meaning “in disguise”.

mn82:42.51.eng: As fruit falls from a tree, so the sons of Manu fall,
mn82:42.51.comm: Māṇava, which normally means “Vedic student”, is occasionally used in the poetic sense of manussa (“humans”). Both words mean “descendant of the first man, Manu”.

mn82:42.52.eng: young and old, when the body breaks up.

mn82:42.53.eng: Seeing this, too, I went forth, O King;

mn82:42.54.eng: the ascetic life is unfailingly better.”
